headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: Sandy Hook, Forever Remembered; Sandy Hook Families Fought For Justice; Alex Jones Mocked Victims' Families; Parents Started A Mission To Help Others. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's been 10 years.

utterances.speaker: NICOLE HOCKLEY, MOTHER OF DYLAN HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: It's a shooting and it's at our school. I literally dropped to the ground. And I thought, oh, gosh, this isn't good.

utterances.speaker: MARK BARDEN, FATHER OF DANIEL BARDEN
utterances.sentences: I was just running into our family van and just flying.

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: -- Since a lone gunman entered Sandy Hook Elementary School and killed 20 children and 6 adults.KAITLIN ROIG-DEBELLIS, FORMER FIRST GRADE TEACHER, SANDY HOOK SCHOOL: It was just so horrific what we heard, my colleagues, children begging for their lives, the entire time thinking that we're going to be next.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And a stunned nation was left grieving.SEN. CHRIS MURPHY (D-CT):  I was sure that Sandy Hook had changed everything. How could you watch that and not decide to do something about it?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Tonight --

utterances.speaker: ALEX JONES, HOST, INFOWARS
utterances.sentences: Don't ever think this couldn't be staged.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- we take you inside the victims' families' battle against harassment and disinformation.

utterances.speaker: SCARLETT LEWIS, MOTHER OF JESSE LEWIS
utterances.sentences: It was the hardest thing I've had to do since my son's murder.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Their fight for change --

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: How did a kid have his hands on an AR-15 semiautomatic assault rifle with a high capacity magazine?

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: We have really hurt a generation of kids by not being able to find ways forward.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- and their vow to stop similar tragedies.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: It's the way I've chose to honor Daniel, to prevent other families from having to endure a life of pain due to preventable violence.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Sandy Hook, Forever Remembered.It was December 14, 2012, just over a week before Christmas.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: That morning, something happened that had never happened before. When I was walking James to the bus, I was aware of little pitter-patter of footsteps behind me in the driveway, and it was Daniel in his little Yankees pajamas. I said, what are you doing up and out? He said, I want to come to the bus with you so I can hug James and tell him I love him. So, I put him on the shoulders and we took James to the bus and he wrapped his little arms around him and hugged him and told him he loved him.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Then, shortly after that, Mark Barden sent his youngest son, Daniel, off to first grade at Sandy Hook Elementary.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: Then it was time to walk him to the bus, and we -- I hugged him and kissed him and told him I loved him.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That same morning, Nicole Hockley and her family were planning a festive day.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: I was planning to go into the school that afternoon. Dylan was in Ms. Soto's class, and it was the day that we were going to be making the ginger bread houses.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But soon after sending their boys to school, Barden and Hockley got emergency phone calls.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This message is from the superintendent of the Newtown Schools. Due to reports of a shooting --

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: A friend called. She said, Nicole, it's a shooting and it's at our school. She was panicking. I literally dropped to the ground.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: I was just in motion. I was just running out of my little studio there and into our family van and just flying and listening to the news and driving.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: First-grade teacher Kaitlin Roig-DeBellis was in the classroom next to the school's entrance, where a lone gunman started shooting his way in.ROIG-DEBELLIS:  We had two minutes from the initial shot that was fired that I heard, which was about ten feet from where we were sitting. So, for us, time was of the essence, and I knew that hiding was the only option.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Roig-DeBellis tried to keep her kids quiet.ROIG-DEBELLIS:  My kids didn't talk a lot because I knew that silence was key.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: You told them that.ROIG-DEBELLIS:  Yes, I said we had to be absolutely quiet. At the beginning initially, I remembered one of my little girls started to cry, understandably so. And so she's crying and I have her face in my hands because I know, right, first graders -- I mean, children, and then after maybe 15 minutes had passed, one of my little boys, who was very boisterous, he still stands out that way to me was (INAUDIBLE), and said, Ms. Roig, I do a really good job at karate with my class every week, and I'm pretty sure that I can take on whoever is bad out there if you let me try, like, let me out. Again, that's a first grader, right?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Roig-DeBellis and her students hid in the bathroom for 45 excruciating minutes.ROIG-DEBELLIS:  And it was a SWAT team that found us. And so all the SWAT members had one or two of my kids and we're just like running. And at this point, I had held it together in the bathroom because I knew I had to with my kids, but at this point, I'm just -- I'm crying. I don't know if I was hysterical. And I'm asking the SWAT team over and over and over again, like, did you really get them? Are they really gone? Like are they in that bush? Are they in that tree?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They were led to a nearby firehouse where parents were waiting.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: In the one room, I could see first graders sitting down with crossed legs, and I kept looking at all the faces, and I didn't see any of Dylan's classmates and I didn't see Dylan.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There's an entire class that has not come out of the school yet.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Nicole Hockley kept scanning the crowd for her six-year-old son.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: I remember just like looking, staring at each one, and just not understanding why he wasn't there. People were holding signs with classrooms, and I found someone holding Ms. Soto's sign, but it wasn't Ms. Soto. And there were just a couple kids there, including Dylan's reading partner. And I walked up and I said, where's the rest of the class? And I looked down at Dylan's reading partner, and she just -- her eyes were, like, wide like saucers, and she was just staring, and -- and I thought, oh, gosh, this isn't good.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Scarlett Lewis was also there, searching for her six-year- old son Jesse.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: I remember being told repeatedly, if you can't find your child, go into the backroom and put his name down on the list. And I'm like, I'm not going to put my child's name down on a list. I'm just going to find him. I tried to go up to the school. They wouldn't let me.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: It was surreal. It was frightening. It was just -- it was hard to process. And at that point, the governor brought everybody into a room in the firehouse. And that's -- that's where we got the news.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: And he said if we were still in that room, that our loved ones weren't coming back.The room erupted. It was chaos. There was wailing, there was screaming, yelling. The gentleman who was to my right was on the ground pounding the floor.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: It was just catastrophic beyond recognition.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Hockley and her husband had to break the awful news to their oldest son, Jake.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: Jake howled like an animal. It was the most disturbing sound I have ever heard in my life because I never heard him make that sound. He just sounded like a wounded animal.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.sentences: There are a lot of days when I wish I hadn't seen the things I saw and heard the things I heard at that firehouse.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Chris Murphy was Connecticut's newly elected U.S. senator.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.sentences: I was there right outside the room when the parents were told by the governor that there were 20 dead kids. You kind of knew that everything was going to change after Sandy Hook.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: When we come back --BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT:  We've endured too many of these tragedies in the past few years. And each time I learn the news, I react not as a president but as anybody else would, as a parent.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The Sandy Hook families take on the fight of their lives.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:13:32] CAMEROTA:  It was the deadliest elementary school shooting in U.S. history.

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: We as a nation, we are left with some hard questions.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In the days and years after, the question remains, how can school shootings be stopped?FMR. GOV. DANNEL MALLOY (D-CT):  Shootings like this are becoming all too common occurrences in our country. It's also a fact that in almost every one of these cases, there were warning signs.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In early 2013, the Connecticut office of the Child Advocate led by Sarah Eagan formed a committee to look for answers.

utterances.speaker: SARAH EAGAN, CONNECTICUT CHILD ADVOCATE
utterances.sentences: The office had been charged with investigating the life of the shooter, to the extent that he intersected with publicly funded services for children, health care, mental health, school, and to issue the most significant findings that we could and what that told us about your need for system change.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They found that the gunman, who took his own life, struggled with untreated mental health issues. Clinical Psychologist Julian Ford was part of the committee.DR. JULIAN FORD, PROFESSOR OF PSYCHOLOGY, UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT HEALTH:  He stayed pretty much to himself. He often wouldn't make eye contact, he often wouldn't speak to others when they spoke to him.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: At age 14, his parents took him to see a psychiatrist test jail Yale School of Medicine's Child Study Center.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The team at Yale recommended medication, along with a special therapeutic school with extensive mental health and educational supports.

utterances.speaker: EAGAN
utterances.sentences: The Yale evaluators cautioned strongly, you know, you can't change the world to meet his needs. We have to give him the tools to live in the world. Otherwise, we're looking at a very negative trajectory.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But the committee found that Yale's recommendations were largely not followed.

utterances.speaker: FORD
utterances.sentences: His mother did try to provide a cocoon for him and keep him from any kind of disturbance that would set him off emotionally. And in so doing, she did exactly what we don't want to have happen, when kids need to have some exposure to stress and challenges in limited and tolerable amounts. CAMEROTADR. KIRSTEN BECHTEL, PROFESSOR OF PEDIATRICS, YALE SCHOOL OF MEDICINE: The only peer relationships he had was sort of on this online gaming world.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Dr. Kirsten Bechtel is an emergency room doctor at Yale Children's Hospital and worked with the committee. She was not involved in the gunman's evaluation by the Yale Child Study Center.

utterances.speaker: BECHTEL
utterances.sentences: There was a lot of violence and a lot preoccupation with war and firearms and things like that.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And guns play a prominent role in his and his family's life.

utterances.speaker: BECHTEL
utterances.sentences: The mother would use this as a way of connecting with her son, and it seemed like it was the only way that she could.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And on December 14th, for reasons still unknown, he shot his mother to death before killing 20 children and 6 staff at Sandy Hook.

utterances.speaker: FORD
utterances.sentences: There is no evidence that any provider, anyone in his life ever thought that he would actually act in such a violent way or anything close to that.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: An investigation by the Connecticut state's attorney found no motive.

utterances.speaker: EAGAN
utterances.sentences: So, we asked about what could have been done differently in his mental health treatment to bring about a different result. I want to underscore the lack of a direct line between mental illness, even untreated, and violence of this nature, which is very rare, right? But the reality is that he didn't have very much mental health treatment, very, very, very, very little.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In the years since the shooting at Sandy Hook, much has changed for kids and mental health in Connecticut.

utterances.speaker: BECHTEL
utterances.sentences: There's much more screening that's done in pediatricians' offices for behavioral health concern.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Connecticut has also become a leader in implementing emergency mobile psychiatric services.

utterances.speaker: BECHTEL
utterances.sentences: Anyone can call 211, and they have trained mental health workers, social workers that come to the home and triage a situation where a child is in a behavioral health crisis. It's been for me, as an E.D. doc, just a game changer and I think for families also.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Dr. Bechtel also says conversations about access to guns are now routine between pediatricians and parents. BECHTEL

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: As the Newtown community grieved their loss, the feeling across the country was that something would finally be done to address gun violence.

utterances.speaker: MUPRHY
utterances.sentences: I was sure that Sandy Hook had changed everything. How could you watch that and not decide to do something about it?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: It was an uphill battle, but many families from Newtown were ready for that fight. Still raw with motion, Nicole Hockley, Mark Barden and many others threw themselves into the battle to enact commonsense gun legislation to spare others from the devastating laws they'd suffered. But this was new to them.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: It was kind of a blissfully, unaware nonpolitical father who played guitar for a living.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: I knew nothing about gun violence in America. I didn't know anything about firearms.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They would need help navigating the treacherous political waters around gun control. Matt Bennett was a policy adviser to the victim's families as they tried to enact gun reform at the federal level.MATT BENNETT, CO-FOUNDER, THIRD WAY:  What I said to them was the obvious thing to do in the wake of this tragedy was to ban assault rifles, the type that were used in this tragedy, and high capacity magazines, but that those things are not going to happen because there's no appetite in Congress. So, what we said was, if we can't get a ban on assault weapons or high capacity magazines, what we need most is to close the loopholes in the background check system. That's the most urgent problem that we face in the gun safety world.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Many families pushed for a bill that required a background check on every gun purchased, closing loopholes for gun shows and online sales. Two senators with A ratings from the NRA stepped forward to sponsor the initiative, Pennsylvania Republican Pat Toomey and West Virginia Democrat Joe Manchin. SEN. JOE MANCHIN (D-WV)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Many of the families traveled to Washington, D.C. several times in 2013 to lobby for the bill.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And did it penetrate?

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: For some, it did. For some, it didn't. Some of them said, you know, my constituents won't understand it this way. And so some stood up and did the right thing, some not so much, some of them lied right to my face.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: As parents were pushing for federal legislation in D.C., many were also calling for policy change back home in Connecticut.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: Connecticut already had good gun laws in place, so this was a strengthening of a lot of them.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: At the time of the shooting, John McKinney was the Republican state senator representing Newtown.

utterances.speaker: MCKINNEY
utterances.sentences: I met with all of the victim's families who asked the meet with me. I told them when I met with them that I viewed my job as to be their voice, to do what they needed me to do for them. Assault weapons and large capacity magazines were really top of mind of the people who talked to me about some of the gun control measures.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In Connecticut, everything was on the table.

utterances.speaker: MCKINNEY
utterances.sentences: One of the things I did was met with all the other Republicans in our caucus, and I was very honest with them. I said I'm going to go negotiate and work with the Democrats on a bill. I'm going to do it as a state senator. I'm going to do it as the leader, but I'm going to do it. And if you're not comfortable with me doing that as your leader, you can have a new leader, and I'll step down. I totally respect that, because I have to do this as their state senator. And, quite frankly, my caucus unanimously said, no, we want you to go in and negotiate and try to work out a bipartisan solution.The emergency certified bill is passed in concurrence with the Senate.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In early April 2013, the Connecticut legislature passed sweeping gun legislation, adding around 100 firearms to an existing assault weapons ban and banning the future sale of magazines with more than ten bullets.

utterances.speaker: MCKINNEY
utterances.sentences: Knowing that the eyes of the country were on us, were on the tragedy in Newtown, maybe we would send a message that some things need to be beyond politics.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Since the law was passed, Connecticut has not had a single shooting with more than three fatalities.After the huge state level win, many families from Newtown were hopeful for a nationwide victory and made the trip to D.C. for the vote in the Senate.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: I was very hopeful at that point because I assumed that we were going to have a victory there.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: I knew that at least 90 percent of Americans wanted to see that happen. I just thought, okay, this is pretty simple. This is basic. This is what everybody wants.JOE BIDEN, U.S. PRESIDENT:  Requiring 60 votes for the adoption of this amendment, the amendment is not agreed to.

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: A minority in the United States Senate decided it wasn't worth it. They blocked commonsense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery. This was a pretty shameful day for Washington.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: I was just -- I was floored. I was absolutely devastated, because I thought with all of the momentum after the shooting, with all of the public polling that showed that people wanted background checks, I received a very hard and devastating lesson on politics that day.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: The gun lobby was able to influence legislators, because when the polls were done, passing that universal background check level at the federal level was polling higher than ice cream and baseball. Over 90 percent of Americans wanted that done. And then it didn't pass.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.sentences: I felt like a failure. I went out of the chamber and said to Mark Barden how sorry I was and that I wasn't going give up, and Mark, I think, looked at me thinking I was hinting he might. And you know, he said to me something along the lines of, Chris, I'm not an advocate for four months. I'm an advocate for 40 years, right? This is my child. I'm never giving up.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: Nobody wants to see a shootout in a school.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Day in and day out, year after year, Hockley, Barden, and many others continued to fight for gun safety legislation. Then in May 2022 --

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Another horrifying night in this country, 19 children, 2 adults gunned down in a small town in a Texas elementary school.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.sentences: What are we doing? Why are you here? If not to solve a problem as existential as this.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: For the first time in a decade, Murphy's Republican colleagues joined him to draft a major gun reform bill.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.sentences: We felt like if we didn't deliver on this issue, when everybody was telling us do something, Republicans, Democrats, independents, it would be cause for a lot of people to totally give up on democracy.About midway through the negotiations, we got to a point where we were ready to announce an agreement. I'll never forget just calling Mark and Nicole and a handful of my other friends to let them know that, you know, something really big was going to happen the next day. We are not going to allow this to become the new normal.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The coalition reached an agreement on enhanced background checks for younger people, funding for state level red flag laws, and a prohibition on gun sales to some domestic abusers.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: The yays are 65. The nays are 33. The motion to concur with an amendment is agreed to.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: This summer, President Biden signed the bipartisan Safer Communities Act into law.NICOLE HOCKLEY, CO-FOUNDER, SANDY HOOK PROMISE:  Americans want change. We have really hurt a generation of kids, and we have really hurt America by not being able find ways forward. And there are ways of coming together, and so let's take one of the most difficult issues on the table right now and figure out a way to come together and make something meaningful happen that will save lives.

utterances.speaker: ALEX JONES, FOUNDER, INFOWARS
utterances.sentences: Don't ever think this couldn't be staged.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Coming up next, the battle against Alex Jones.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: While the victim's families struggled to cope with their loss, they were also grappling with a haunting question.MARK BARDEN, CO-FOUNDER, SANDY HOOK PROMISE:  How did a kid across the neighborhood have his hands on an AR-15 semi-automatic assault rifle with a high-capacity magazine?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That question led them to some advertising by the manufacturer, Remington Arms.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: They were saying, get your man card here. Imagery of a lone gunman. The next best thing to enlisting with a military background. Those weapons are the number one choice for people when they want to kill a lot of people in a short amount of time, because that's what they're designed to do in a military battlefield context.But when somebody wants to shoot up in elementary school or church, that's the weapon of choice because that's what it does.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: We started to talk about different lawsuits, and I'd already been shopping around to different law firms saying, you know, there's something here. What can we do?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And what were you hearing from those law firms?

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: No, every single one that I spoke to said, it's unwinnable.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Unwinnable because of a 2005 U.S. law that protects firearm manufacturers from being held liable when crimes are committed with their weapons. But the families did find one attorney willing to take a chance, Joshua Koskoff.

utterances.speaker: JOSHUA KOSKOFF, ATTORNEY FOR SANDY HOOK FAMILIES
utterances.sentences: We know that sometime after the 154th and last bullet was fired, at least from the assault weapon --I think I probably was being ignorant of how challenging the laws where I come from a long line of trial lawyers and we were our very idealistic, even if the case was impossible to win.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: While the federal law protecting gun manufacturers did provide some level of immunity, it was not a total shield. There were exceptions including one that allowed for lawsuits if there's proof that the manufacturer knowingly violated state or federal law.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: They were engaged in a reckless advertising campaign that was, yielding deadly results.

utterances.speaker: KOSKOFF
utterances.sentences: OK, thank you everybody, for coming.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The families of nine victims and one survivor sued the gun manufacturer. Claiming that Remington's ads targeted unstable young men and emphasized the gun's ability to exact mass casualties.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: They used totally irresponsible strategies. I wanted to send a message to everyone that markets to our kids and young adults that they need to be responsible in that marketing.

utterances.speaker: KOSKOFF
utterances.sentences: You can imagine the appeal this type of marketing would have on a adolescent who is in the throes of anxiety or feeling, weak unmanly and saw in this weapon the answer to all their problems.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The case dragged on for years with Remington appealing all the way up to the Supreme Court, which declined to hear the case. Finally, earlier this year, a settlement was announced with the now bankrupt Remington, and its four insurers.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Gun maker Remington has reached a $73 million settlement with some of the families of children and adults killed in the horrific massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

utterances.speaker: HOCKLEY
utterances.sentences: Nothing will bring Dylan back. The closest I get to him now is by kissing his urn every night. Telling him I love him and I miss him, but I made him a promise and I'll keep working to deliver that promise for the rest of my life.I do get emotional about the victories, about making change, about seeing a thought, a strategy actually come into something that is going to work and make a difference. And this was years of work.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The families agreed to a settlement that included $73 million. But more importantly, the right to disclose thousands of pages of internal company documents.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: We have all of their internal documents, all of their advertising strategies, and all of the thinking and all the planning that went into that. We'd like to take meaningful steps on creating some guardrails around what is OK and what's not OK with regard to marketing practices especially marketing firearms and weapons to children.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The lawsuit against Remington would not be the family's only battle in court. In the immediate aftermath of the shooting at Sandy Hook, conspiracy theorist, Alex Jones took to his podcast and questioned whether the massacre had ever even happened.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So, don't ever think the globalists that have hijacked this country wouldn't stage something like this. They kill little kids all day, every day. Don't ever think this couldn't be staged. Now --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Followers of Jones web site, Infowars began a year's long campaign harassing the victim's families.

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: I started getting this ugly filth, people claiming that I was a crisis actor, that Daniel never existed.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Barden, Lewis, Hockley, and the families of other Sandy Hook victims, and one first responder filed separate defamation lawsuits against Alex Jones in Texas and Connecticut.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: He -- he's a worse actor than Glen Beck.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: With bullying behavior, you first try to ignore it, and then when it doesn't stop, you have to find the courage to stand up to it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: The 1984 tyranny is 1776. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: When the court case got underway, Alex Jones refused to turn over discovery documents required by the court. So, Jones was ruled liable by default.

utterances.speaker: KOSKOFF
utterances.sentences: What was left was what's called a hearing and damages. So, the only issue left after that was what was the extent of the harm. And to some extent, the extent of the wrongdoing that Mr. Jones engaged in.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Come have a seat in the witness chair.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: BARDEN
utterances.sentences: The goal is to prevent other families from having to endure a life of pain due to preventable violence, and that is what we are doing. And how are you doing that?

utterances.sentences: It took a lot of research to understand that 100 percent of school shooters give off warning signs, 100 percent every single one.

I still haven't grieved Dylan to this day. I've still never grieved Dylan, and I'm scared to. But I've seen what could be done. I've seen that we can stop these things.
